awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Advanced biomanufacturing with inducible feedback promoters
awd_abstract_narration:
Producing chemicals using microbes and biomass is an alternative to processes that use petroleum as a raw material. Performing this at a commercial scale is difficult. This project will develop a new tool to improve microbial chemical production. The tool will use the microbe's ability to sense its environment to improve performance. The microbes will produce a variety of industrial chemicals. Outreach to the community will take many forms. One involves hands-on demonstrations in a local high school and elementary school serving underrepresented populations. The broader public will be engaged through booths at Chicago-area Maker Faires. These activities are designed to stimulate interest in biology as a tool to solve societal challenges. They should also expand the pool of students pursuing STEM careers and entering the biomanufacturing workforce.


IFPs (inducible feedback promoters) represent a new regulatory concept for metabolic pathway control and optimization. They combine naturally occurring stress responsive feedback with purely inducible timing control. Inducibility allows titration and timing of pathway expression to be rapidly explored. Stress responsive feedback allows autonomous expression optimization. The central objective is to develop and validate IFPs in the context of two industrially important metabolic pathways: terpenoid oxygenation and n-butanol production. This objective will be pursued through aims that validate the approach of IFP regulation in each pathway. We will create a community resource of unique IFPs applicable to diverse metabolic pathways. IFPs that are directly relevant for industrial bioprocess application will be fine-tuned using autonomous timing control through quorum-sensing and biosensors. These efforts will be done in collaboration with industry partners who will provide critical perspective to allow development of IFPs that provide the greatest possible value to industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
In this project, significant strides were made in developing and applying a novel tool called riboregulated switchable feedback promoters (rSFPs) for precise, dynamic control of gene expression in bacteria. This technology holds promise for expanding the capabilities of synthetic biology and biomanufacturing.  rSFPs utilize small RNA regulators (STARs) to control stress-response promoters involved in envelope, acid, and toxin response pathways. This allows for fine-tuned gene expression in response to environmental cues, enhancing cell robustness and optimizing production yields.  rSFPs were successfully applied to regulate the production of valuable compounds like Taxol precursors and amorphadiene. In both cases, rSFPs were able to control for complex metabolic processes with increased efficiency.  Expanding the rSFP toolkit, glucose sensing and quorum sensing circuits were interfaced with rSFPs, enabling auto induction and control based on specific environmental conditions. This opens doors for even more precise and adaptable production strategies.

In a different thrust, the effect of engineering stress response pathways to enhance protein synthesis was examined. Stress engineered cells showed increased limonene titers. The underlying mechanism appears to be suppression of stress pathways that normally limit protein synthesis. By relaxing this repression, stress engineering allows cells to remain highly metabolically active, resulting in increased limonene output.  While the exact reason for enhanced protein synthesis remains unclear, the overall findings highlight the importance of considering stress response pathways for optimizing metabolic engineering strategies. These findings also point towards potential ways to further improve limonene production by exploring additional stress response modifications and unraveling the unique behavior of stress engineered cells.

Beyond the technical advancements, the project has also made significant contributions to education and outreach. Researchers integrated biotechnology research topics into K-12 curricula through school and after-school programs. Graduate students taught STEM-based enrichment activities that fostered scientific curiosity and knowledge among young learners. Additionally, group members participated in career panels and public events, promoting broader understanding and appreciation for synthetic biology.


Last Modified: 12/19/2023
Modified by: Keith E Tyo
